awd_titl_txt: EAGER: SUPER: Light and Warm Polariton Driven Superconductors (PoDS)
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract

This EAGER project aims to utilize light to control electron flow, so as to turn an electronic material into a conductor of zero resistance--a superconductor--under readily accessible conditions.  Superconductivity at accessible temperatures and pressure has been one of the key research objectives in quantum physics and materials science.  Once realized, it would have enormous impact on society, from energy efficiency of the electrical grid to thermal management of integrated chips and reduced electrical consumption.  The team will perform a combined theoretical-experimental study to explore a new pathway toward this goal, utilizing coherent light (lasers) to "drive" electrons into a superconducting state, via integrating novel quantum materials with specially designed photonic structures.  In addition, graduate and undergraduate students will be trained on a wide range of state-of-the-art theoretical and experimental tools and techniques through a close theory-experiment collaboration at the cross-disciplinary cutting edge of condensed-matter physics, quantum optics, low-dimensional materials, and nano-photonics.


Technical Abstract

Superconductivity is a crown jewel of modern condensed-matter physics.  Although the fundamental mechanism of a Bardeen-Cooper-Schrieffer superconductor has been understood since the 1950s, higher critical temperature continues to be a grand challenge, as we have been mostly at the mercy of material properties given by nature.  In recent years, however, technologies have been developed to exert unprecedented control over materials to alter or even to engineer their properties.  Motivated by recent theoretical discoveries of new superconducting mechanisms, breakthroughs in van der Waals heterostructures, and advances in sophisticated photonic structures, the team will explore a potentially more versatile and practical pathway toward high Tc--polariton driven superconductors--where a highly controllable, high-temperature polariton superfluid provides a new mechanism for Cooper-pair formation.  The project will develop the fundamental understanding and key technologies for a new type of superconductor controllable by light, including how to use an ultra-light superfluid to introduce and control strong pairing potentials between electrons in the proximity, effects and limitations of electron band dispersion, and the influence of dimensionality on superconductivity.  It will advance multiple research frontiers spanning materials science, quantum photonics, condensed-matter physics, theoretical physics, and potentially particle physics through the deep connection between the Anderson-Higgs mechanism in superconductors and the Higgs mechanism in particle physics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This EAGER project aims to utilize light to control electron flow, so as to turn an electronic material into a conductor of zero resistance--a superconductor--under readily accessible conditions.  Superconductivity at accessible temperatures and pressure has been one of the key research objectives in quantum physics and materials science.  Once realized, it would have enormous impact on society, from energy efficiency of the electrical grid to thermal management of integrated chips and reduced electrical consumption. 

Intellectual merit:

The team has performed a combined theoretical-experimental study to explore a new pathway toward this goal, utilizing coherent light (lasers) to "drive" electrons into a superconducting state, via integrating novel quantum materials with specially designed photonic structures. 

Specifically, the team identified a system that may host superconductivity at high transition temperatures – liquid nitrogen temperature or higher that are easy to access and afford – and are realistic to implement in experimentally with known materials and technologies. The system utilizes a few recent developments in novel materials and theoretical modeling. The theory model we developed for the system is exactly solvable, so the superconducting phase diagram can be calculated exactly once the material parameters are known. The model also predicts more exotic phases at higher temperature than the superconducting transition temperature, which have been notoriously difficult to attain or understand but are believed to be important understanding many types of high-temperature superconductors.

The team has also developed new methods to create high quality materials and cavities structures reliably and in an affordable way. Such materials and cavities are critical for experimental implementation of the theoretically identified high-temperature superconductor systems, but have not been available or very difficult to obtain with existing methods.

Broader Impact:

The theoretical model developed in the project points a new way to realize high-temperature superconductivity. The techniques and mechanisms can also be generalized to other systems, providing a generic framework for future studies of novel types of superconductive systems, and may impact broadly research and applications of superconductors including in quantum information science. The new methods of fabrication the materials and material-cavity integrated systems have solved major technological challenges in 2D materials research. They may broadly impact the research and development of those novel materials and devices for future photonics technologies. The results have been disseminated through multiple publications and numerous scientific presentations. The PIs have given multiple public lectures on light and electrons and how they impact modern technology.

Furthermore, the project has provided research training and various professional development to eight graduate students, two master student and three undergraduate students, including training on a wide range of state-of-the-art theoretical and experimental tools and techniques through a close theory-experiment collaboration at the cross-disciplinary cutting edge of condensed-matter physics, quantum optics, low-dimensional materials, and nano-photonics.
